intro: Rhysolepis bishopii, commonly known as Bishop's rhyolepis, is a rare and endemic plant species found in specific regions of the western United States. It is a member of the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its shrub-like growth habit. The plant typically features small, leathery leaves and produces clusters of bell-shaped flowers that are usually pink or white in color. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is adapted to harsh, alpine or subalpine environments. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
